docs.title: Music Logger Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the official documentation for the Music Logger app.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This site contains all legal and privacy-related information regarding the usage of the Music Logger app and its services.

  • Privacy Policy

docs.title: 1. Scope of Application
docs.text:

docs.title: 2. Description of Services
docs.text:
(1) Music Logger is an app for the automated recognition and logging of music played at events, parties, or comparable occasions.

(2) The App captures exclusively the following information:

  • Recognized song title
  • Recognized artist (author)
  • Time of playback
  • Location of usage (event or location reference)

(3) The following are NOT captured or stored:

  • Conversations or voice recordings
  • Voices of individuals
  • Other audio content outside of music
  • Personal data of guests or third parties

(4) The App serves specifically for the documentation of played music, the analysis of playlists, and the avoidance of song duplications.

(5) Music recognition is performed automatically via external music recognition interfaces (APIs), utilizing technologies such as Shazam and ACRCloud.

(6) The average recognition accuracy of the App is approx. 80%. A complete or error-free recognition of all played songs is technically not possible.

(7) The functionality of the App is particularly restricted or excluded if:

  • unreleased songs or songs not recorded in databases are played,
  • songs are heavily altered in their speed, pitch, or structure,
  • there is no internet connection or an unstable internet connection,
  • the audio quality at the recording location is insufficient.

(8) There is no claim to successful music recognition in every individual case.

docs.title: 3. Activation and Consent
docs.text:
(1) Music recognition occurs exclusively following active usage by the user. Recording does not take place automatically and not without the user's knowledge.

(2) By using the App, the user confirms that they are authorized to perform music recognition at the respective location and that no third-party rights are being infringed.

docs.text:
(1) Use of the App requires the creation of a user account (Login).

(2) The user is obligated to provide truthful information during registration and to keep their access data confidential.

(3) The provider is entitled to block or delete user accounts in the event of violations of these GTC.

docs.title: 5. Cost Model
docs.text:
(1) Music Logger is offered in a free basic version as well as in paid subscription models.

(2) The respective scope of functions depends on the selected tariff.

(3) Prices, terms, and cancellation conditions of the subscriptions are displayed transparently prior to the conclusion of the contract and form part of the contract.

docs.title: 6. Display and Export of Logs
docs.text:
(1) Users can view their recorded music logs:

  • within the App and
  • export them in suitable file formats.

(2) The responsibility for the further use, transfer, or publication of the exported data lies exclusively with the user.

docs.title: 7. User Obligations
docs.text:
(1) The App must not be used:

  • for the surveillance of persons,
  • for secret recording in private spaces,
  • for illegal or abusive purposes.

(2) The user ensures that the use of the App does not violate applicable laws, domiciliary rights (house rules), or contractual obligations.

docs.text:
(1) No guarantee is assumed for the completeness, correctness, or recognition accuracy of the music recognition.

(2) The provider is not liable for:

  • incorrect or incomplete song recognitions,
  • technical failures or restrictions,
  • consequences resulting from the use of the captured data.

(3) The provider assumes no responsibility for GEMA, licensing, or copyright obligations of the users.

(4) The provider is not liable for restrictions resulting from the use of external music recognition services (e.g., Shazam API, ACRCloud), lack of internet connection, or altered music parameters.

(5) The App represents a supporting documentation tool and not a legally binding or evidentiary protocol.

docs.text: The provider strives for high availability of the App but owes no uninterrupted use.

docs.text: Information regarding the processing of personal data is regulated in the separate Privacy Policy, which is an integral part of usage.

(1) Users may terminate their user account at any time.

(2) The provider is entitled to terminate the contract without notice in the event of serious violations of these GTC.

docs.title: 2. Audio Recognition & Microphone
docs.text:
To provide music recognition features, "Music Logger" requires access to your device's microphone (android.permission.RECORD_AUDIO). We are committed to protecting your privacy and ensuring transparency regarding how this data is handled.

Key Information on Data Processing:

  • No Permanent Storage: No audio recordings are permanently stored on your device.
  • No Audio Transmission: No raw audio files are ever transmitted to our servers or any third parties.
  • Local Processing: The audio stream is processed directly on your device to generate a unique digital fingerprint.
  • Third-Party Services (ACRCloud & Shazam): Only this anonymous digital fingerprint (which cannot be converted back into audio) is sent to our recognition providers, such as ACRCloud or Apple (Shazam), solely for the purpose of retrieving song metadata (Title, Artist).

We do not listen to, record, or store your conversations or environment audio for any other purpose.

docs.title: 3. Data Processing via Recognition Providers
docs.text:
To identify songs, we use external services provided by ACRCloud and Apple (Shazam).

  • Purpose: Music Recognition.
  • Data Transmitted: Digital Fingerprints (No raw audio).
  • Legal Basis: Your Consent (Art. 6 (1) (a) GDPR), which you grant by allowing microphone access in the app.

docs.title: 4. Your Rights
docs.text:
Under the GDPR, you have the following rights regarding your data:

  • Right to Access & Correction: You can ask for details about the data we hold.
  • Right to Deletion: You can request the deletion of your data.
  • Right to Withdraw Consent: You can revoke the microphone permission at any time in your device settings. This stops all data processing immediately.
  • Right to Complain: You have the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority if you believe your privacy rights have been violated.

docs.title: Testing Strategy
docs.text: This document outlines the testing philosophy and priorities for the Music Logger project. Given the current development phase (active feature development, design not finalized), we prioritize logic and stability over visual regression testing.

docs.title: 1. Core Philosophy
docs.text: Functionality First, Aesthetics Later. Our primary goal is to ensure the application is reliable in a live environment (clubs, events). A crash during a set is unacceptable. Visual perfection is secondary until the design is finalized.

docs.title: ✅ Priority 1: Robustness & Resilience ("Unhappy Paths")
docs.text:
The app runs for hours in unstable environments. We must test failure states as rigorously as success states.

  • Network Stability: What happens if the internet cuts out for 1 second? 1 minute?
  • API Failures: Handling timeouts (e.g., ACRCloud/Shazam API not responding) gracefully without crashing the UI.
  • Resource Management: Verify that timers and streams are disposed of correctly to prevent memory leaks during long sessions.

docs.title: ✅ Priority 2: Algorithmic Verification
docs.text:
Logic that involves calculation or complex state transitions must be verified in isolation (Pure Unit Tests).

  • Time & Drift: Verify calculations for drift compensation and timestamping independent of the system clock or UI.
  • Logic Isolation: Test the mathematical formulas and parsing logic without spinning up the UI or Simulator.

docs.title: ✅ Priority 3: Test Hygiene & Isolation
docs.text:
To maintain a healthy test suite, we strictly adhere to:

  • Tabula Rasa: Every test starts with a clean state. No shared state between tests.
  • Fixtures: Use static data files for API responses instead of dynamic or real network calls.
  • Determinism: Tests must produce the same result every single time.

docs.title: ⏸️ Visual Regression ("Golden Tests")
docs.text: Status: Postponed. Since the UI/UX design is still iterating, pixel-perfect tests (Golden Tests) would be too brittle and require constant maintenance. * Plan: We will introduce Golden Tests only for critical, stable screens (e.g., the main logging view) once the design is frozen.
